"}, {'created': '2019-11-26 15:23:57.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Enforce unified limits using oslo.limit

A new configuration option is added for operators to opt in to unified
limit enforcement. To opt in, you must set:

   [quota]
   use_unified_limits = True

When use_unified_limits is True, the existing quota enforcement is
hardcoded to use the NoopQuotaDriver. When it is False, all the new
unified limits enforcement doesn't apply. This means where you want to
apply both the existing quotas and unified limits, you simply ensure
that both existing quotas and unified limits are checked. The underlying
frameworks will ensure the configuration is respected.

Long term, subject to operator feedback, we hope to remove the existing
quota system, and leave only unified limits.
We assume the use of the placement counting logic here, and that all
migration of data that is needed has already been done.

Many existing quotas are not being moved to unified limits. These can be
grouped into two categories:

* api request based limits (metadata_items, injected files)
* db count based limits (keypairs, server_groups, server_group_members)

These limits are now only set via configuration, there is no API in
either Nova or Keystone that will influence the limits applied. In
addition, the limits are now global to all projects and users, i.e. we
loose the option to have per project overrides.

TODO: no consensus on this yet!
In addition, the above limits are also not rechecked following the DB
changes that are made to see if there was a race between the check and
DB call between different API workers. This is so we move towards a much
simpler system in the long term.

As such, existing quota enforcement will have one of the following calls
added after it:

* local_limit.enforce_api_limit
* local_limit.enforce_db_limit
* keystone_limit.enforce

blueprint unified-limits-nova

NOTE:
This uses my own hacked up oslo.limit lib to try and show what sort of
interface might work.
Depends-On: I294a922ea80af673291c991f07a4a203f25c289d

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11

"}, {'created': '2020-03-16 17:49:41.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Enforce resource limits using oslo.limit

When use_unified_limits = True, we now enforce resource limits. This
includes: instances, ram, cores. It also works for any resource class
being requested via the flavor chosen, such as custom resource classes
relating to Ironic resources.

Follow on patches will update the APIs to accurately report the limits
being applied to instances, ram and cores.

TODO: been splitting the large patches, but still need to:
* changes after this one to update the apis to query and set limits in
  keystone, etc.
* nova_manage to export something for keystone manage, help with
  transition

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11
'}, {'created': '2020-03-25 11:33:44.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Enforce resource limits using oslo.limit

We now enforce limits on resources requested in the flavor.
This includes: instances, ram, cores. It also works for any resource
class being requested via the flavor chosen, such as custom resource
classes relating to Ironic resources.

Note because disk resources can be limited, we need to know if the
instance is boot from volume or not. This has meant adding extra code to
make sure we know that when enforcing the limits.

Follow on patches will update the APIs to accurately report the limits
being applied to instances, ram and cores.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11

commit_message:
Enforce resource limits using oslo.limit

We now enforce limits on resources requested in the flavor.
This includes: instances, ram, cores. It also works for any resource
class being requested via the flavor chosen, such as custom resource
classes relating to Ironic resources.

Note because disk resources can be limited, we need to know if the
instance is boot from volume or not. This has meant adding extra code to
make sure we know that when enforcing the limits.

Follow on patches will update the APIs to accurately report the limits
being applied to instances, ram and cores.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11

subject: Tell oslo.limit how to count nova resources

Note we also need patches for setting quota, and passthing through through to keystone. That was left as a TODO when I did my first pass on all this."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-06-07 15:53:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-06-07 15:57:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Note we also need patches for setting quota, and passthing through through to keystone. That was left as a TODO when I did my first pass on all this.

Do we? I would think it would be reasonable to say that the quota API is read-only if delegated to keystone. Sort of like how we proxy things out of neutron to keep user-facing things consistent, but we don't let you manage neutron via nova anymore. Seems fine to make that change to me. It'll be a lot less work, validation, and something we could eventually deprecate and remove from Nova down the road."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2021-06-08 08:19:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> Patch Set 7:
> 
> > Note we also need patches for setting quota, and passthing through through to keystone. That was left as a TODO when I did my first pass on all this.
> 
> Do we? I would think it would be reasonable to say that the quota API is read-only if delegated to keystone. Sort of like how we proxy things out of neutron to keep user-facing things consistent, but we don't let you manage neutron via nova anymore. Seems fine to make that change to me. It'll be a lot less work, validation, and something we could eventually deprecate and remove from Nova down the road.

It was operator push back, they wanted to keep the existing tooling working. But frankly, as you can see, I was hedging on us deciding against it. I like the reasons you mention, and it roughly comes under the "no more proxy" stance.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-06-08 13:41:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> It was operator push back, they wanted to keep the existing tooling working. But frankly, as you can see, I was hedging on us deciding against it. I like the reasons you mention, and it roughly comes under the "no more proxy" stance.

Yeah. We could also maybe hide it in either of the clients to keep the commands working or something, but I would say that would be a good point of "compromise" to keep the complexity down in hopes of ever getting some of this kind of stuff done :)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-07-29 02:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-16 17:49:41.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Tell oslo.limit how to count nova resources

A follow on patch will use this code to enforce the limits, this patch
provides integration with oslo.limit and a new internal nova API that is
able to enforce those limits.

The first part is providing a callback for olso.limit to be able to count
the resources being used. We only count resources grouped by project_id.

For counting servers, we make use of the instance mappings list in the
api database, just as the existing quota code does. While we do check to
ensure the queued for delete migration has been completed, we simply
error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in
placement using consumer records, or similar.

For counting all other resource usage, they must refer to some usage
relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code
works today. This is not restricted to RAM and VCPU, it is open to any
resource class that is known to placement.

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar
signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

TODO: Currently the disk is always enforced, because boot from volume
isn't known at this point in the code?

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698

"}, {'created': '2021-09-23 05:06:24.000000000', 'message': "Tell oslo.limit how to count nova resources

A follow on patch will use this code to enforce the limits, this patch
provides integration with oslo.limit and a new internal nova API that is
able to enforce those limits.

The first part is providing a callback for oslo.limit to be able to count
the resources being used. We only count resources grouped by project_id.

For counting servers, we make use of the instance mappings list in the
api database, just as the existing quota code does. While we do check to
ensure the queued for delete migration has been completed, we simply
error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in
placement using consumer records, or similar.

For counting all other resource usage, they must refer to some usage
relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code
works today. This is not restricted to RAM and VCPU, it is open to any
resource class that is known to placement.

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar
signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

A [workarounds] option is also available for operators who need the
legacy quota usage behavior where VCPU = VCPU + PCPU.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698

error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in
placement using consumer records, or similar.

For counting all other resource usage, they must refer to some usage
relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code
works today. This is not restricted to RAM and VCPU, it is open to any
resource class that is known to placement.

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar
signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

A [workarounds] option is also available for operators who need the
legacy quota usage behavior where VCPU = VCPU + PCPU.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698

commit_message:
Tell oslo.limit how to count nova resources

A follow on patch will use this code to enforce the limits, this patch
provides integration with oslo.limit and a new internal nova API that is
able to enforce those limits.

The first part is providing a callback for oslo.limit to be able to count
the resources being used. We only count resources grouped by project_id.

For counting servers, we make use of the instance mappings list in the
api database, just as the existing quota code does. While we do check to
ensure the queued for delete migration has been completed, we simply
error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in
placement using consumer records, or similar.

For counting all other resource usage, they must refer to some usage
relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code
works today. This is not restricted to RAM and VCPU, it is open to any
resource class that is known to placement.

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar
signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

A [workarounds] option is also available for operators who need the
legacy quota usage behavior where VCPU = VCPU + PCPU.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-02-04 13:08:36.000000000', 'message': "Fix request id

This patch fixes 3 issues related to request ids:

- Duplicated request ID in logs
- Missing request id header in response
- Wrong request ID in response header when using noauth

The first two are caused by the same issue, which is the fact that
requests that don't require authorization (those that go to / to get
available versions) don't set a context and resuse the previous one.

And the last bug is fixed as a freebie when the code in auth.py is
refactored to reduce code duplication on setting the cinder.context key
in the request's environment.

Not sure if values now defined in ENV_OVERWRITES are still necessary,
so the patch preserver current behavior.

Close-Bug: #1960019
Close-Bug: #1960020
Close-Bug: #1960021
Change-Id: Ide831a221a7561bbb7da193f0edb011f1989420e
"}, {'created': '2022-02-08 15:47:05.000000000', 'message': "Fix request id mess on Cinder-API

This patch fixes multiple issues related to request ids:

- Duplicated request ID in logs
- Missing request id header in response
- Wrong request ID in response header when using noauth

The source of these issues is the fact that the request ID and the
request context are set too late, or not at all, in the paster filter

commit_message:
Fix request id mess on Cinder-API

This patch fixes multiple issues related to request ids:

- Duplicated request ID in logs
- Missing request id header in response
- Wrong request ID in response header when using noauth

The source of these issues is the fact that the request ID and the
request context are set too late, or not at all, in the paste filter
chain.

And the last bug is fixed as a freebie when the code in auth.py is
refactored to reduce code duplication on setting the cinder.context key
in the request's environment.

The patch fixes these issue by changing the filter chains to have the
request_id filter as the first filter, and using our own filter for it,
to ensure that the context is correctly set.

Not sure if values now defined in ENV_OVERWRITES are still necessary,
so the patch preserves current behavior.

Closes-Bug: #1960019
Closes-Bug: #1960020
Closes-Bug: #1960021
Closes-Bug: #1960329
Change-Id: Ide831a221a7561bbb7da193f0edb011f1989420e

commit_message:
Update quota sets APIs

Ensure the limit related APIs reflect the new reality of enforcing the
API and DB limits based on keystone only.

For now we skip all updates to the DB, as none mean anything to the new
code, as we only look at keystone now.

Note: this will need to be updated again once we add limits for
cores, ram, instances, etc.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I5ef968395b4bdc6f190e239a19a723316b1d5baf

commit_message:
Add missing microversion entry for 3.67

Change I3729cbe1902ab4dc335451d13ed921ec236fb8fd merged
implementing microversion 3.67 but missed an entry in
the microversions.py file.
This patch addresses the same.

Change-Id: Ifd30ee86e657ddda9746eddcd080557520b1d468

commit_message:
Update limit APIs

Ensure the limit related APIs reflect the new reality of enforcing the
API and DB limits based on keystone. Do this by implementing the
get_project_quotas and get_user_quotas methods.

This still leaves get_settable_quotas and get_defaults that are needed to
fix the quota sets APIs.

Note: this will need to be updated again once we add limits for
cores, ram, instances, etc.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I3c4c29740e6275449887c4136d2467eade04fb06

subject: Update quota_class APIs for db and api limits

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-10 17:45:24.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Update quota_class APIs for db and api limits

Implement a unified limits specific version of get_class_quotas as used
by the quota_class API.

Note: this will need to be updated again once we add limits to things
that use things like resource_class, etc.

Change-Id: If9901662d30d15da13303a3da051e1b9fded72c0
'}, {'created': '2020-03-12 12:39:22.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Update quota_class APIs for db and api limits

Implement a unified limits specific version of get_class_quotas as used
by the quota_class API.

Note: this will need to be updated again once we add limits to things

commit_message:
Update quota_class APIs for db and api limits

Implement a unified limits specific version of get_class_quotas as used
by the quota_class API. This simply returns the limits defined in
keystone that are now enforced when you enable unified limits.

Note: this will need to be updated again once we add limits to things
that use things like resource_class, etc.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: If9901662d30d15da13303a3da051e1b9fded72c0

The ``get_os_codename_package`` function will be called by all
charms.  The newly added call to the ``configure_source`` method
may in some circumstances raise an exception due to missing

Handle this situation gracefully.

commit_message:
core: Gracefully handle missing config option

The ``get_os_codename_package`` function will be called by all
charms.  The newly added call to the ``configure_source`` method
may in some circumstances raise an exception due to missing
source configuration option.

Handle this situation gracefully.

Related-Bug: #1951462
Change-Id: I2bb9c2561b89fea366bd7b7f6a10c3140ce09000

I'm not really sure why we're building more of these sorts of limits into config files, even though these *are* generally global. If someone has to change these, they have to reconfigure/redeploy and bump all the API services before the effect can be had.

To me, we should be building more towards a model where we utilize config-as-a-service or a central definition for lots of things, and unified limits works for us in this regard. It would be trivial to just expect people to set these global limits as registered limits in keystone and likely never override them per-project, but then they get that for free if they want to (like for one specific project that runs over because it houses all of CI or something). We can cache those things so we're not constantly hitting keystone, but I guess it just seems like this is a perfect example of something that doesn't need to be in the config (except maybe a default, but even still...). Downstream right now, we're having discussions about how painful config-based things are to change at runtime with containers, especially when they have to change atomically across all the API workers in order to avoid confusing people with one request failing and another succeeding due to the load balancer.

So, I dunno, I guess I'm not vehemently opposed to this, but it seems like an odd move in the wrong direction to me :/"}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-08-17 18:04:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

I think that all makes sense and it would also make reasoning about it simpler if we were to put all limits in keystone, IMHO. Having two different places for limits confuses me at least, after I've not looked at the implementation for awhile. I'll reach out to John to try and get his thoughts about changing the direction for the global limits to be in keystone instead."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2021-08-18 19:07:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> Patch Set 14:
> 
> I think that all makes sense and it would also make reasoning about it simpler if we were to put all limits in keystone, IMHO. Having two different places for limits confuses me at least, after I've not looked at the implementation for awhile. I'll reach out to John to try and get his thoughts about changing the direction for the global limits to be in keystone instead.

IIRC at the Denver PTG, the idea to put some limits in keystone and other limits in config was driven by if the resource was actually a physical resource or not (e.g., vCPUs versus ssh key pairs).

In summary, folks felt better putting "simple" resource limits in configuration. But, some of that might have been due to sticker shock as we fully wrapped our minds around the unified limit dance that needs to happen in each service just to do something reasonable with a create resource request (e.g., fetch limits from keystone, calculate usage, process the request, recalculate usage, etc). I'm only bringing this up to provide the for historical context and that I think the original reasoning was coupled to keeping the initial work as simple as possible. Now that unified limits is further along the adoption phase, maybe we need to revisit that assumption.

I'm all for consistency, so if folks are open to using unified limits for everything in their service I think that's great and makes a big difference for operators (and simplifies configuration).'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-08-18 19:17:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> I'm all for consistency, so if folks are open to using unified limits for everything in their service I think that's great and makes a big difference for operators (and simplifies configuration).

Yeah, we're getting strong desires for things like this to not be in config and require config management to be involved when something needs to change. IMHO, config should largely be for structural things (like here is my database connection). Maybe even API rate limits belong there as they're tied to absolutes and such. Anything that is a limit worth potentially tweaking, *especially* if it could need a tweak for an exceptional tenant, would better be in the same place as all the other limits. I think that someone not familiar with the internals would not really understand or appreciate why they need to tweak the limit for one thing globally and with a service restart, where another can be tweaked via API at runtime without config management.

Keystone only knows that there's a limit, and that there's potentially a per-project override. The "this looks like a quota of consumables" notion is really only a thing in oslo.limit. AFAIK, Glance was the first real implementation to use this stuff, and it already had to work around oslo.limit's quota behavior, even to implement quotas for consumable resources. I added the calculate functionality to oslo.limit so I could fix some of that, and was required before I could even add an API. So, I definitely think we should consider keystone's unified limits as just limits, and let projects apply them to quotas of things, or limits on actions, or whatever. I feel pretty sure that the operators will appreciate those knobs all being in one place.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-08-18 19:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Thanks Lance for sharing that context.

Unrelated to that, thinking about it more, it seems like putting certain limits in keystone would be awkward and potentially misleading. A couple of things that came to mind:

(1) There is no way to "discover" the resource name one needs to use to "map" the limit to the counting. We would need to pick specific names, "keypairs" for example, that operators would need to know to pass when creating limits in order for nova to count and enforce the limit. For resources in placement, the resource names are discoverable via the API. In this patch series, "servers" are currently an exception to that and they will be countable in placement once [1] lands.

(2) Example: keypairs exist on a per user basis. A registered limit makes sense here but a project limit does not. We cannot count keypairs per project as nova does not store the project_id in the key_pairs database table. A user would likely expect keypairs to be enforced per project if they had set a project limit, but there is no way to do that. Is there a way to have a registered limit that does not allow a project limit to be set? If so, then maybe this would be fine as it would not give operators incorrect expectations of a project scoped enforcement in cases like this.

Thoughts?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:%22bp%252Fsupport-consumer-types%22'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-08-18 20:09:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> (1) There is no way to "discover" the resource name one needs to use to "map" the limit to the counting. We would need to pick specific names, "keypairs" for example, that operators would need to know to pass when creating limits in order for nova to count and enforce the limit. For resources in placement, the resource names are discoverable via the API. In this patch series, "servers" are currently an exception to that and they will be countable in placement once [1] lands.

I think this exists for every case that people are going to use for these; they'll have to discover them in some way or another. For things in placement, they're discoverable via the placement API. For glance, we had to document them of course, because how else would they know?

https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/quotas.html#quota-resource-types

Nova has a quota on instances, which isn't a placement resource type. Surely nova isn't going to keep that in its own database instead of putting it in keystone forever right? However, instances is a great example where normally the same limit could be applied to everyone, except for the tenant for a CI system which needs to be able to grow much larger, but still needs an upper bound. Same for volumes, ports, etc. I think all the other projects that do this will have to define what resource names need to be set in keystone at bootstrap time, like many other things (service accounts, etc). Surely we could standardize the mechanism by which you get these. Maybe something slick like:

 $ nova-manage limits defaults | openstack registered limit create -

Another option would be to make keystone or oslo.limit start defaulting to -1 instead of 0 when a limit doesn't exist. So, if you do nothing, you have no limits, but things don't break. Either seem reasonable to me.

> (2) Example: keypairs exist on a per user basis. A registered limit makes sense here but a project limit does not. We cannot count keypairs per project as nova does not store the project_id in the key_pairs database table. A user would likely expect keypairs to be enforced per project if they had set a project limit, but there is no way to do that. Is there a way to have a registered limit that does not allow a project limit to be set? If so, then maybe this would be fine as it would not give operators incorrect expectations of a project scoped enforcement in cases like this.

Yeah, this is a fair point and it's probably a useful topic to bring up, especially in the face of system scoped things, where some resources may need to be limited which aren't project (or user) scoped. The keypairs per user thing has always been a little bit of an oddball in nova being scoped per user instead of project (as we've noted before with one employee quitting and an instance becoming inaccessible to the rest of her team), so it's no surprise that it's breaking the mold here as well.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2021-08-18 20:47:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Mel, thanks for pushing on these. Dan thanks for the careful review and good ideas, as ever.

So I remember why I wrote Oslo.limit in such an obscure way now. I was fixated with two level hierarchy limits. I wanted common logic to count resources and compare with limits in keystone to be in common code. Thus, anything not in that project resource model I excluded. Granted it makes my multi instance logic horrendous (face palm).

Instance count we planned as resource consumer record count, or something like that. Either way that should move to keystone. I thought I moved that one anyways, as it fits the project model just fine?

> Surely we could standardize the mechanism by which you get these. Maybe something slick like:
>  $ nova-manage limits defaults | openstack registered limit create -

FWIW, that looks like what I wanted us to do, only nicer.

> Another option would be to make keystone or oslo.limit start defaulting to -1 instead of 0 when a limit doesn't exist. So, if you do nothing, you have no limits, but things don't break.

I wanted to avoid this default to Open, it seemed a risky default, but it would work. Not totally against it.

> > (2) Example: keypairs exist on a per user basis. A registered limit makes sense here but a project limit does not. We cannot count keypairs per project as nova does not store the project_id in the key_pairs database table. A user would likely expect keypairs to be enforced per project if they had set a project limit, but there is no way to do that. Is there a way to have a registered limit that does not allow a project limit to be set? If so, then maybe this would be fine as it would not give operators incorrect expectations of a project scoped enforcement in cases like this.
> 
> Yeah, this is a fair point and it's probably a useful topic to bring up, especially in the face of system scoped things, where some resources may need to be limited which aren't project (or user) scoped. The keypairs per user thing has always been a little bit of an oddball in nova being scoped per user instead of project (as we've noted before with one employee quitting and an instance becoming inaccessible to the rest of her team), so it's no surprise that it's breaking the mold here as well.

Yes, ruddy keypairs. I am not against only looking up only the default in this case.

So maybe we have three Oslo.limit types / interfaces:

* per project countable resource  (with hierarchy implications, i.e. current model)
* get per project absolute limit (might inherit its limit from parent project, but nothing to count from the parent project)
* get global limit (ignore all project overrides, i.e. the keypair hack)

On reflection moving everything to keystone sounds better. Except nova-network rubbish. I think the above means we still get hierarchy working correctly."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-08-18 21:20:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

> So I remember why I wrote Oslo.limit in such an obscure way now. I was fixated with two level hierarchy limits. I wanted common logic to count resources and compare with limits in keystone to be in common code. Thus, anything not in that project resource model I excluded. Granted it makes my multi instance logic horrendous (face palm).

I definitely have a hard time grasping how current oslo.limit can move from flat to two-level without a different interface. I also have a hard time understanding how it's really going to be used, in part because it's only two-levels and not n-levels. Not to say that two doesn't cover most people's need, but I also kinda wonder if flat is actually all we need (at least, at this point). That said, these are oslo.limit constructs and not anything to do with keystone, which is why I think that if we need oslo.limit to better support a generic non-quota-like limit, we should be fine to add that.

> Instance count we planned as resource consumer record count, or something like that. Either way that should move to keystone. I thought I moved that one anyways, as it fits the project model just fine?

Yeah, was just using it as a counter-example to the "only limit things from placement, because they're discoverable there." I'm sure we're on the same page that it should be in keystone too :)

> > Surely we could standardize the mechanism by which you get these. Maybe something slick like:
> >  $ nova-manage limits defaults | openstack registered limit create -
> 
> FWIW, that looks like what I wanted us to do, only nicer.

++ I already defended the "but how will people know what to set?" questions when I did the glance implementation. I did it with docs, but the above would be better. Sounds like you were already ahead of me on that (as always!)

> > Another option would be to make keystone or oslo.limit start defaulting to -1 instead of 0 when a limit doesn't exist. So, if you do nothing, you have no limits, but things don't break.
> 
> I wanted to avoid this default to Open, it seemed a risky default, but it would work. Not totally against it.

Well, to be fair, I've used both sides of this argument in various conversations. On the one hand, I think it'd be easier at bootstrap time because we wouldn't have to register everything before we use it. On the other hand, not reading that page of the docs might lead to an escalation the first night after GA :)

> > > (2) Example: keypairs exist on a per user basis. A registered limit makes sense here but a project limit does not. We cannot count keypairs per project as nova does not store the project_id in the key_pairs database table. A user would likely expect keypairs to be enforced per project if they had set a project limit, but there is no way to do that. Is there a way to have a registered limit that does not allow a project limit to be set? If so, then maybe this would be fine as it would not give operators incorrect expectations of a project scoped enforcement in cases like this.
> > 
> > Yeah, this is a fair point and it's probably a useful topic to bring up, especially in the face of system scoped things, where some resources may need to be limited which aren't project (or user) scoped. The keypairs per user thing has always been a little bit of an oddball in nova being scoped per user instead of project (as we've noted before with one employee quitting and an instance becoming inaccessible to the rest of her team), so it's no surprise that it's breaking the mold here as well.
> 
> Yes, ruddy keypairs. I am not against only looking up only the default in this case.

I left my English-to-English dictionary at home, but I trust "ruddy" means what I think it does from context. Yes, looking up with a None or zero-uuid project for keypairs would be a fine start, until we decide how or what to do about that.

> So maybe we have three Oslo.limit types / interfaces:
> 
> * per project countable resource  (with hierarchy implications, i.e. current model)
> * get per project absolute limit (might inherit its limit from parent project, but nothing to count from the parent project)
> * get global limit (ignore all project overrides, i.e. the keypair hack)
> 
> On reflection moving everything to keystone sounds better. Except nova-network rubbish. I think the above means we still get hierarchy working correctly.

That's fine, but I also think that someone needs to finish the oslo.limit hierarchy (read: two-level) implementation before I can really understand how it's going to be used. I certainly don't want to dig ourselves a hole based on a multi-level future we can't ever get to or that doesn't end up being useful.

Note that I already implemented something kinda between your second and third bullet, which is the calculate_usage() interface in oslo.limit. It lets you probe the limit and usage of each without enforcing, which glance will need for the data pipeline and for its API. Modulo a buglet identified by Melwitt if the operator hasn't registered a limit, I think that's a useful more general-purpose thing we can use for both your second bullets. It "supports" two-level in that it calls into that Enforcer, but the interface is NotImplementedError there just like the regular one at the moment. So I think that would work for the alternate cases, potentially with a change to allow providing no count function or something to always get a usage of zero or something.

So, sounds like we're converging on consensus here. I'm going to upgrade my vote to a -1 because gibi has a +2 on here and I don't want anyone coming along and ignoring all the good discussion :)

Melanie, I'm like swamped in glance policy refactor stuff, but I will commit to trying to fix the bug in my limit thing. If you're going to take over this stuff in nova, feel free to pester for further reviews when you're ready.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-08-18 22:13:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> So, sounds like we're converging on consensus here. I'm going to upgrade my vote to a -1 because gibi has a +2 on here and I don't want anyone coming along and ignoring all the good discussion :)
> 
> Melanie, I'm like swamped in glance policy refactor stuff, but I will commit to trying to fix the bug in my limit thing. If you're going to take over this stuff in nova, feel free to pester for further reviews when you're ready.

Indeed it sounds like we have a way forward which addresses the majority of the discussed issues. \o/

Yes, I'll do my best to change over the global limits from config => keystone in this patch series (with apologies to John in advance for messing up his patches) unless John wants to do it, of course.

And thank you both for the productive discussion :)"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2021-08-18 22:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1
> 
> > So I remember why I wrote Oslo.limit in such an obscure way now. I was fixated with two level hierarchy limits. I wanted common logic to count resources and compare with limits in keystone to be in common code. Thus, anything not in that project resource model I excluded. Granted it makes my multi instance logic horrendous (face palm).
> 
> I definitely have a hard time grasping how current oslo.limit can move from flat to two-level without a different interface. I also have a hard time understanding how it's really going to be used, in part because it's only two-levels and not n-levels. Not to say that two doesn't cover most people's need, but I also kinda wonder if flat is actually all we need (at least, at this point). That said, these are oslo.limit constructs and not anything to do with keystone, which is why I think that if we need oslo.limit to better support a generic non-quota-like limit, we should be fine to add that.

This is all too useful to be blocked by hierarchy IMHO. Agreed on doing what is needed.

This is what I wrote to convince myself of the current approach, although I suspect it has massive flaws:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.limit/+/695527

> > > Another option would be to make keystone or oslo.limit start defaulting to -1 instead of 0 when a limit doesn't exist. So, if you do nothing, you have no limits, but things don't break.
> > 
> > I wanted to avoid this default to Open, it seemed a risky default, but it would work. Not totally against it.
> 
> Well, to be fair, I've used both sides of this argument in various conversations. On the one hand, I think it'd be easier at bootstrap time because we wouldn't have to register everything before we use it. On the other hand, not reading that page of the docs might lead to an escalation the first night after GA :)

+1
I remember why default to 0 not -1. It was typo protection, if an operator added vpcpus or something like that by accident.

> > > > (2) Example: keypairs exist on a per user basis. A registered limit makes sense here but a project limit does not. We cannot count keypairs per project as nova does not store the project_id in the key_pairs database table. A user would likely expect keypairs to be enforced per project if they had set a project limit, but there is no way to do that. Is there a way to have a registered limit that does not allow a project limit to be set? If so, then maybe this would be fine as it would not give operators incorrect expectations of a project scoped enforcement in cases like this.
> > > 
> > > Yeah, this is a fair point and it's probably a useful topic to bring up, especially in the face of system scoped things, where some resources may need to be limited which aren't project (or user) scoped. The keypairs per user thing has always been a little bit of an oddball in nova being scoped per user instead of project (as we've noted before with one employee quitting and an instance becoming inaccessible to the rest of her team), so it's no surprise that it's breaking the mold here as well.
> > 
> > Yes, ruddy keypairs. I am not against only looking up only the default in this case.
> 
> I left my English-to-English dictionary at home, but I trust "ruddy" means what I think it does from context. Yes, looking up with a None or zero-uuid project for keypairs would be a fine start, until we decide how or what to do about that.

+1

> > So maybe we have three Oslo.limit types / interfaces:
> > 
> > * per project countable resource  (with hierarchy implications, i.e. current model)
> > * get per project absolute limit (might inherit its limit from parent project, but nothing to count from the parent project)
> > * get global limit (ignore all project overrides, i.e. the keypair hack)
> > 
> > On reflection moving everything to keystone sounds better. Except nova-network rubbish. I think the above means we still get hierarchy working correctly.
> 
> That's fine, but I also think that someone needs to finish the oslo.limit hierarchy (read: two-level) implementation before I can really understand how it's going to be used. I certainly don't want to dig ourselves a hole based on a multi-level future we can't ever get to or that doesn't end up being useful.

I don’t think we should block on understanding two level. Although I would love eyes on this:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.limit/+/695527

I think it implements semantics we wrote up here:
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/rocky/strict-two-level-enforcement-model.html

Granted, I should really have unit tests for all cases in that spec, at a minimum.

> Note that I already implemented something kinda between your second and third bullet, which is the calculate_usage() interface in oslo.limit. It lets you probe the limit and usage of each without enforcing, which glance will need for the data pipeline and for its API. Modulo a buglet identified by Melwitt if the operator hasn't registered a limit, I think that's a useful more general-purpose thing we can use for both your second bullets. It "supports" two-level in that it calls into that Enforcer, but the interface is NotImplementedError there just like the regular one at the moment. So I think that would work for the alternate cases, potentially with a change to allow providing no count function or something to always get a usage of zero or something.

Oh neat, yes. Usage count of zero is what we return in the API for all the strange cases anyways for a project count. Actually that really would tidy up these patches quite a lot. And fixes the interface you need to calculate the instance count.

With two level you would need to list of dicts with project/limit/count entries, with one entry for the requested project, then one for each step up the hierarchy, if there are any, with parent projects always returning counts that include all descendants. Two level gets max two entries, but works for general n-level case I think.

The enforcer is able to hide those details for the caller. Sounds like we can’t hide those differences here. Actually allows for better error messages I think. Hmm, maybe we should ditch the enforcer. I prefer your new interface, especially if it returns a list of limit and usage that two level could add two. Seems like a looser coupling. I think my enforcer has a slight fail early without counting everything advantage, but it’s probably a premature optimisation.

> So, sounds like we're converging on consensus here. I'm going to upgrade my vote to a -1 because gibi has a +2 on here and I don't want anyone coming along and ignoring all the good discussion :)
> 
> Melanie, I'm like swamped in glance policy refactor stuff, but I will commit to trying to fix the bug in my limit thing. If you're going to take over this stuff in nova, feel free to pester for further reviews when you're ready.

I had writers block fixing the instance count issue. Dan’s new interface totally fixes that.

I so want to fix this now, but my next two days are blocked out, and I am on holiday the following week. I wish the story would change but seems unlikely right now. Mel, if you have bandwidth, it would be awesome if you could rework it in a more timely way.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2021-08-18 23:21:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> With two level you would need to list of dicts with project/limit/count entries, with one entry for the requested project, then one for each step up the hierarchy, if there are any, with parent projects always returning counts that include all descendants. Two level gets max two entries, but works for general n-level case I think.

Hmm, well, not sure that will fit into the interface I defined without some massaging because the dict is just resource:limit, not a list. The reason I defined what I did is because I thought that the enforcer would calculate what the limit was from the data available and still provide you one result. Basically "Okay I've looked at your bank account and decided that after rent and utilities, you have $3 left for pizza". If it's not going to do that (or can't?) then maybe we'll have to fudge a bit in terms of the "stable" interface we're providing there.

> The enforcer is able to hide those details for the caller. Sounds like we can’t hide those differences here. Actually allows for better error messages I think. Hmm, maybe we should ditch the enforcer. I prefer your new interface, especially if it returns a list of limit and usage that two level could add two. Seems like a looser coupling. I think my enforcer has a slight fail early without counting everything advantage, but it’s probably a premature optimisation.

Well, I think the enforcer is a useful construct to have for the straightforward case, but as melwitt has already noted, it does sometimes generate some confusing error messages in some situations and obviously isn't always applicable. I think for my interface we just need to make it boil down the limit to what it would enforce, and then report that instead of enforce. If we can do that regardless of the flat or hierarchical approach, I think the caller should get the same info and be happy.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2021-08-19 15:52:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-08-29 03:18:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2021-08-29 05:37:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-10 17:45:24.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Enforce api and db limits

When using unified limits, we add enforcement of those limits on all
related API calls. Note: we do not yet correctly report the configured
limits to users via the quota APIs, that is in a future patch.

Note the unified limits calls are made alongside the existing legacy
quota calls. The old quota calls will be handed by the quota engine
driver, that is basically a no-op. This is to make it easier to remove
the legacy code paths in the future.

Note, to ease integration, the exceptions raised match those raised by
the existing exception code, regardless of the strange nature of the
information passed back to the caller via an exception. The user of the
API will see the same return values, no matter which code is enabled to
enforce the limits.

TODO: need to double check test coverage here.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I36e82a17579158063396d7e55b495ccff4959ceb

'}, {'created': '2020-03-16 13:17:33.000000000', 'message': 'Enforce api and db limits

When using unified limits, we add enforcement of those limits on all
related API calls. Note: we do not yet correctly report the configured
limits to users via the quota APIs, that is in a future patch.

Note the unified limits calls are made alongside the existing legacy
quota calls. The old quota calls will be handed by the quota engine
driver, that is basically a no-op. This is to make it easier to remove
the legacy code paths in the future.

Note, to ease integration, the exceptions raised match those raised by
the existing exception code, regardless of the strange nature of the
information passed back to the caller via an exception. The user of the
API will see the same return values, no matter which code is enabled to
enforce the limits.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I36e82a17579158063396d7e55b495ccff4959ceb

'}, {'created': '2021-08-29 03:18:18.000000000', 'message': 'Enforce api and db limits

When using unified limits, we add enforcement of those limits on all
related API calls. Note: we do not yet correctly report the configured
limits to users via the quota APIs, that is in a future patch.

Note the unified limits calls are made alongside the existing legacy
quota calls. The old quota calls will be handed by the quota engine
driver, that is basically a no-op. This is to make it easier to remove
the legacy code paths in the future.

Note, over quota exceptions raised with unified limits use the standard
(improved) exception message as those raised by oslo.limit. They
however do use the existing exception code to ease integration. The
user of the API will see the same return codes, no matter which code is
enabled to enforce the limits.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I36e82a17579158063396d7e55b495ccff4959ceb

'}, {'created': '2022-02-02 03:35:45.000000000', 'message': 'Enforce api and db limits

When using unified limits, we add enforcement of those limits on all
related API calls. Note: we do not yet correctly report the configured
limits to users via the quota APIs, that is in a future patch.

Note the unified limits calls are made alongside the existing legacy
quota calls. The old quota calls will be handed by the quota engine
driver, that is basically a no-op. This is to make it easier to remove
the legacy code paths in the future.

Note, over quota exceptions raised with unified limits use the standard
(improved) exception message as those raised by oslo.limit. They
however do use the existing exception code to ease integration. The
user of the API will see the same return codes, no matter which code is
enabled to enforce the limits.

Finally, this also adds test coverage where it was missing. Coverage
for "quota recheck" behavior in KeypairAPI is added where all other
KeypairAPI testing is located. Duplicate coverage is removed from
nova/api/openstack/compute/test_keypairs.py at the same time.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I36e82a17579158063396d7e55b495ccff4959ceb

commit_message:
Enforce api and db limits

When using unified limits, we add enforcement of those limits on all
related API calls. Note: we do not yet correctly report the configured
limits to users via the quota APIs, that is in a future patch.

Note the unified limits calls are made alongside the existing legacy
quota calls. The old quota calls will be handed by the quota engine
driver, that is basically a no-op. This is to make it easier to remove
the legacy code paths in the future.

Note, over quota exceptions raised with unified limits use the standard
(improved) exception message as those raised by oslo.limit. They
however do use the existing exception code to ease integration. The
user of the API will see the same return codes, no matter which code is
enabled to enforce the limits.

Finally, this also adds test coverage where it was missing. Coverage
for "quota recheck" behavior in KeypairAPI is added where all other
KeypairAPI testing is located. Duplicate coverage is removed from
nova/api/openstack/compute/test_keypairs.py at the same time.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I36e82a17579158063396d7e55b495ccff4959ceb

'}, {'created': '2022-01-21 21:50:55.000000000', 'message': 'expirer: Only try to delete containers if it might succeed

Which is to say, if all the tasks we saw in the container were actually

'}, {'created': '2022-01-21 22:50:04.000000000', 'message': 'expirer: Only try to delete containers if it might succeed

Which is to say, if all the tasks we saw in the container were actually

Change-Id: I8c3f78d1d1850ab501180f884f81f84552617fb7
'}, {'created': '2022-02-11 00:08:01.000000000', 'message': "expirer: Only try to delete empty containers

Currently, the object-expirer is a little delete-happy -- after a
container gets processed, an attempt is always made to delete it,
even if we know it will fail with a 409 because either

    * we found items that this worker won't process (see the
      process/processes config options) or

    * we encountered failures processing items and thus didn't
      pop all the records off the queue that we *could* process.

The failed DELETE has downsides such as

    * adding unnecessary load to the container servers (though
      the 409 can hopefully be serviced fairly quickly) and

    * evicting container info and listing shard ranges from
      memcache, which

    * can further load the container-servers (if the expiry queues
      have gotten large enough to shard), as all the expirers
      doing listings now have to go fetch shard ranges directly
      from the DB.

Now, only attempt to delete an expiry container if it appears to be
empty. In any reasonably-sized cluster, we expect dozens to hundreds of
concurrent expirers to be processing the expiry queues. Seeing the
container empty is the most reliable signal that the delete is expected
to succeed.

Change-Id: I8c3f78d1d1850ab501180f884f81f84552617fb7
"}]
commit_message:
expirer: Only try to delete empty containers

Currently, the object-expirer is a little delete-happy -- after a
container gets processed, an attempt is always made to delete it,
even if we know it will fail with a 409 because either

    * we found items that this worker won't process (see the
      process/processes config options) or

    * we encountered failures processing items and thus didn't
      pop all the records off the queue that we *could* process.

The failed DELETE has downsides such as

    * adding unnecessary load to the container servers (though
      the 409 can hopefully be serviced fairly quickly) and

    * evicting container info and listing shard ranges from
      memcache, which

    * can further load the container-servers (if the expiry queues
      have gotten large enough to shard), as all the expirers
      doing listings now have to go fetch shard ranges directly
      from the DB.

Now, only attempt to delete an expiry container if it appears to be
empty. In any reasonably-sized cluster, we expect dozens to hundreds of
concurrent expirers to be processing the expiry queues. Seeing the
container empty is the most reliable signal that the delete is expected
to succeed.

Change-Id: I8c3f78d1d1850ab501180f884f81f84552617fb7

commit_message:
Updating python testing classifier as per Yoga testing runtime

Yoga testing runtime[1] has been updated to add py39
testing as voting. Unit tests update are handled by the
job template change in openstack-zuul-job

- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/+/820286

this commit updates the classifier in setup.cfg file.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/yoga.html

Change-Id: I152b7110fac106b81d541b30d82df438f214f28f

revisions:
[{'created': '2022-02-14 05:07:05.000000000', 'message': 'Modify remaining APIs as per RBAC new guidelines

As per the RBAC new direction, we will allow
project resources operation to be performed by
the project scoped token only and system user will
be allowed to perform system level operation only
not project resources specific.

Details about new direction can be found in community-wide
goal
- https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html

This commit modify remaining APIs as per the new guidelines.

Also modifying and adding tests for four cases:
1. enforce_scope=False + legacy rule (current default policies)
2. enforce_scope=False + No legacy rule
3. enforce_scope=True + legacy rule
4. enforce_scope=True + no legacy rule (end goal of new RBAC)

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-2

Change-Id: I006d47aa2f4678a06c78057bcf407302abbe4907

- https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html

This commit modify remaining APIs as per the new guidelines.

Also, allow all project admin to list the other project limits. This is
what we allowed in legacy policy and until we have domain admin or other
way to list other project resources/info, we will keep that behaviour.

Also modifying and adding tests for four cases:
1. enforce_scope=False + legacy rule (current default policies)
2. enforce_scope=False + No legacy rule
3. enforce_scope=True + legacy rule
4. enforce_scope=True + no legacy rule (end goal of new RBAC)

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-2

Change-Id: I006d47aa2f4678a06c78057bcf407302abbe4907

commit_message:
Modify remaining APIs as per RBAC new guidelines

As per the RBAC new direction, we will allow
project resources operation to be performed by
the project scoped token only and system user will
be allowed to perform system level operation only
not project resources specific.

Details about new direction can be found in community-wide
goal
- https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html

This commit modify remaining APIs as per the new guidelines.

Also, allow all project admin to list the other project limits. This is
what we allowed in legacy policy and until we have domain admin or other
way to list other project resources/info, we will keep that behaviour.

Also modifying and adding tests for four cases:
1. enforce_scope=False + legacy rule (current default policies)
2. enforce_scope=False + No legacy rule
3. enforce_scope=True + legacy rule
4. enforce_scope=True + no legacy rule (end goal of new RBAC)

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-2

Change-Id: I006d47aa2f4678a06c78057bcf407302abbe4907

commit_message:
Release final python-senlinclient for Yoga

This is a release for python-senlinclient to get any merged but unreleased
changes out prior to the client lib freeze for Yoga going into effect.

If the team is ready to proceed, please leave a +1 to acknowledge this
release and we will process right away. If the team is working on any
final merges, leave a -1 with some detail on the status and update the
patch with the new commit hash to use when ready.

Patches with no response will be merged by Friday, February 25th.

$ git log --oneline --no-merges 2.3.0..9fc2edc
6b78b4a Add Python3 yoga unit tests
960d3a9 Update master for stable/xena
7cb1233 Use py3 as the default runtime for tox
d0b16e5 Add Python3 xena unit tests
46ffa06 Update master for stable/wallaby

Signed-off-by: Elod Illes <elod.illes@est.tech>
Change-Id: I3286783ae76578e8f17828e3a93f40a77945c3d3

commit_message:
Server actions APIs scoped to project scope

As per the RBAC new direction, we will allow
project resources operation to be performed by
the project scoped token only and system user will
be allowed to perform system level operation only
not project resources specific.

Details about new direction can be found in community-wide
goal
- https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html

This commit modify the server action APIs to be scoped
to project scope.

Fix the shelve-offload policy to pass the instance project
id as target.

Also modifying and adding tests for four cases:
1. enforce_scope=False + legacy rule (current default policies)
2. enforce_scope=False + No legacy rule
3. enforce_scope=True + legacy rule
4. enforce_scope=True + no legacy rule (end goal of new RBAC)

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-2

Change-Id: I5293e9aa9cb3b48f97a5a2cf272939ada1aea2db

commit_message:
Fix functional CI job

The glanceclient-dsvm-functional job is currently running unit
tests, whereas it should be running the functional tests.  Fixed
by honoring the path in .stestr.conf like other trees.

Also removed tox.ini from the list of irrelevant-files for this
job, because as it turns out, it is relevant.

Change-Id: I59773caa00ff0dfc970c0e4d45aa5d8ae006b1c6

commit_message:
Update qcow test to use qcow2 instead

qemu-img package for Centos 8 doesn't support qcow disk format anymore,
due to this, tests using qcow are failing with
`Unknown file format 'qcow'`.
This patch updates the qcow tests for qcow2 instead.

Closes-Bug: #1946457

Change-Id: If488ae4299a6cab521eec9c5e9ce4f29f94057e1
(cherry picked from commit 947e541fc0f7c0fc2b759898ab8b9401d152f3d0)

commit_message:
Mock tenacity in gluster driver unit tests

We're going into a long wait loop when the retrying
logic kicks in in some unit tests:

manila.tests.share.drivers.glusterfs.test_common.GlusterManagerTestCase.test_set_vol_option_error_1                                                        511.046
manila.tests.share.drivers.glusterfs.test_common.GlusterManagerTestCase.test_set_vol_option_error_2                                                        511.040

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I9eafbfe0cb806d05525a3b17c43d92f0f5fbfac1

commit_message:
[ceph-mon] Change configmap names to be based on release names

This change makes the ceph-mon configmap names dynamic based on
release name to match how the ceph-osd chart is naming configmaps.
The new ceph-mon post-apply job needs this in some cases in order
not to have conflicting configmap names in separate releases.

Change-Id: Id26d0a8310ccff80a608e25d2b0a74a41f9e6a55

[{'created': '2021-11-11 18:11:59.000000000', 'message': 'Add debug log for scheduler weight calculation

We have all the weighers enabled by default and each can have its own
multiplier making the final compute node order calculation pretty
complex. This patch adds some debug logging that helps understanding how
the final ordering was reached.

Change-Id: I7606d6eb3e08548c1df9dc245ab39cced7de1fb5
'}]
commit_message:
Add debug log for scheduler weight calculation

We have all the weighers enabled by default and each can have its own
multiplier making the final compute node order calculation pretty
complex. This patch adds some debug logging that helps understanding how
the final ordering was reached.

Change-Id: I7606d6eb3e08548c1df9dc245ab39cced7de1fb5

[{'created': '2021-12-16 14:04:21.000000000', 'message': 'Reattach mdevs to guest on resume

When suspending a VM in OpenStack, Nova detaches all the mediated
devices from the guest machine, but does not reattach them on the resume
operation. This patch makes Nova reattach the mdevs that were detached
when the guest was suspended.

This behavior is due to libvirt not supporting the hot-unplug of
mediated devices at the time the feature was being developed. The
limitation has been lifted since then, and now we have to amend the
resume function so it will reattach the mediated devices that were
detached on suspension.

Closes-bug: #1948705

Signed-off-by: Gustavo Santos <gustavofaganello.santos@windriver.com>
Change-Id: I083929f36d9e78bf7713a87cae6d581e0d946867
(cherry picked from commit 16f7c601b63bd1e7ca13917261300a7064ec72bc)

commit_message:
Reattach mdevs to guest on resume

When suspending a VM in OpenStack, Nova detaches all the mediated
devices from the guest machine, but does not reattach them on the resume
operation. This patch makes Nova reattach the mdevs that were detached
when the guest was suspended.

This behavior is due to libvirt not supporting the hot-unplug of
mediated devices at the time the feature was being developed. The
limitation has been lifted since then, and now we have to amend the
resume function so it will reattach the mediated devices that were
detached on suspension.

Closes-bug: #1948705

Signed-off-by: Gustavo Santos <gustavofaganello.santos@windriver.com>
Change-Id: I083929f36d9e78bf7713a87cae6d581e0d946867
(cherry picked from commit 16f7c601b63bd1e7ca13917261300a7064ec72bc)

[{'created': '2021-11-30 13:03:18.000000000', 'message': 'Log which instance event was timed out

Nova compute logs what external events it waits for and logs if timeout
happens but it is not easy to figure out which even are timed out if
nova waits for multiple events, i.e.: there are multiple ports to be
plugged.

This patch moves the warning log into wait_for_instance_event itself and
extends the log with the name of the event nova waited for when the
timeout happens.

Change-Id: I91c42af8226dc8607d86c52413924351ba0586ac
'}, {'created': '2021-12-09 17:47:17.000000000', 'message': 'Log which instance event was timed out

Nova compute logs what external events it waits for and logs if timeout
happens but it is not easy to figure out which even are timed out if
nova waits for multiple events, i.e.: there are multiple ports to be
plugged.

This patch moves the warning log into wait_for_instance_event itself and
extends the log with the name of the event nova waited for when the
timeout happens.

Change-Id: I91c42af8226dc8607d86c52413924351ba0586ac
'}]
commit_message:
Log which instance event was timed out

Nova compute logs what external events it waits for and logs if timeout
happens but it is not easy to figure out which even are timed out if
nova waits for multiple events, i.e.: there are multiple ports to be
plugged.

This patch moves the warning log into wait_for_instance_event itself and
extends the log with the name of the event nova waited for when the
timeout happens.

Change-Id: I91c42af8226dc8607d86c52413924351ba0586ac

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-09-15 15:43:07.000000000', 'message': 'Get ports directly instead of via loop

In order to get a list of available ports, the current implementation
of the form code in `project/instances/attach_interface` loops through
the available networks in the project and requests a list of ports for
each. This implementation is O(N) in time with a large prefactor (the
time for a Neutron API call) where N is the number of networks.

This change re-implements this particular part and uses one call to
the Neutron API to get the list of all ports and filters this list.
While this implementation is still O(N) the prefactor is significantly
smaller.

Closes: https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1943639

Change-Id: I8fd32c3aad22d8ef7f57201f5144f6b2e357ef10
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>
'}, {'created': '2021-09-15 15:54:41.000000000', 'message': 'Get ports directly instead of via loop

In order to get a list of available ports, the current implementation
of the form code in `project/instances/attach_interface` loops through
the available networks in the project and requests a list of ports for
each via the Neutron API. This implementation is O(N) in time with a
large prefactor (the time for a Neutron API call) where N is the
number of networks.

Instead of calling the Neutron API for each network this change uses
one call to the Neutron API to get the list of ports on all networks
and filters this list via a list comprehension. While this
implementation is still O(N) the prefactor is significantly smaller.

Closes: https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1943639
Change-Id: I8fd32c3aad22d8ef7f57201f5144f6b2e357ef10
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>
'}, {'created': '2021-09-16 14:28:35.000000000', 'message': 'Get ports directly instead of via loop

number of networks.

Instead of calling the Neutron API for each network this change uses
one call to the Neutron API to get the list of ports on all networks
and filters this list via a list comprehension. While this
implementation is still O(N) the prefactor is significantly smaller.

Closes-Bug: #1943639
Change-Id: I8fd32c3aad22d8ef7f57201f5144f6b2e357ef10
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>

and filters this list via a list comprehension. While this
implementation is still O(N) the prefactor is significantly smaller.

Closes-Bug: #1943639
Change-Id: I8fd32c3aad22d8ef7f57201f5144f6b2e357ef10
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Get ports directly instead of via loop

In order to get a list of available ports, the current implementation
of the form code in `project/instances/attach_interface` loops through
the available networks in the project and requests a list of ports for
each via the Neutron API. This implementation is O(N) in time with a
large prefactor (the time for a Neutron API call) where N is the
number of networks.

Instead of calling the Neutron API for each network this change uses
one call to the Neutron API to get the list of ports on all networks
and filters this list via a list comprehension. While this
implementation is still O(N) the prefactor is significantly smaller.

Closes-Bug: #1943639
Change-Id: I8fd32c3aad22d8ef7f57201f5144f6b2e357ef10
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Use neutron client for server.addresses

The server.addresses (/servers/{server_id}/ips)
endpoint can contain stale data causing attribute
lookups to fail.

This change replaces the use of server.addresses
and instead uses the neutron client to list ports
with 'device_id' matching the server id.

Story: 2008632
Task: 41843
Related: RHBZ#1902230
Change-Id: I1b9293041f2ad92eac0e9bc9646e7b2d7c6f7fd0
(cherry picked from commit 45750c603ac9965afd5b4e53ecff65977b887b95)

Apologies for the delay in the update ... I had some analysis paralysis trying to decide whether to organize the patches in a different way given that this new proposal has all of the quota limits in keystone (no more quota limit config option use).

Eventually I went forward with a mostly "in-place" changeover from config options => keystone limits for the API and DB resources. I have spun it as: nova/limit/local.py contains the logic for resources that are either values in API request params or are resources that live in the nova database.

In this patch I introduce oslo.limit for the ability to pull registered limits from keystone. I also added "server_" to the limits assuming we need to namespace them in some way since unified limits are global to all projects.

In later patches I changed: nova/limit/keystone.py => nova/limit/placement.py to contain the logic for resources that live in placement. The obvious exception to this is "servers" but that is intended to be temporary as consumer types has landed in placement and once nova is using consumer types, we will be able to tell the difference between an "instance" allocation and "migration" allocations and thus use the distinction to count servers from placement.

Let me know whether you think this should be organized differently ... I also might have missed rewriting some code comments or commit messages properly to reflect the new direction. I will fix those too if any are spotted.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2021-08-29 03:33:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

> Patch Set 13:
> 
> Eventually I went forward with a mostly "in-place" changeover from config options => keystone limits for the API and DB resources. I have spun it as: nova/limit/local.py contains the logic for resources that are either values in API request params or are resources that live in the nova database.

To be clear, I am using the "local" term to mean resources "local to nova". I was thinking that merging the content of nova/limit/local.py and nova/limit/keystone.py into nova/limit/keystone.py would be too large/complex or more difficult to read.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2021-08-29 05:51:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-10 17:45:24.000000000', 'message': "Add logic to enforce local api and db limits

Future patches will make use of this logic, and actually enforce the
limits. This patch just adds the infrastructure to allow for the
enforcement of the limits.

We are not moving all existing quotas to be managed via Keystone's
unified limits. Many of the quotas that we previously allowed to be
overridden via the database, will now only be set via Nova
configuration.

These limits are all about preventing excessive load on the API and
database and have little to do with resource usage. As discussed over
several years at operators meetups, all operators seemed happy to
simplify the system by only setting these limits via configuration.

Local limits include things that just limit items in an API request:
* metadata_items
* injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes

Local limits also include things that are stored in the database:
* key_pairs
* server_groups
* server_group_members

Note that each of the above are counted via a different scope. This new
code ensures that key_pairs are counted per user, server_groups are
counted per project and server_group_members are counted per
server_group.

Note: Previously server_group_member were counted per user inside each
server_group, which has proved very confusing, as adding more users into
a project increases the maximum size of allowed for a server_group.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I0b6f4d29aaee1d71541a95cbecfd0708aac325d2

limits. This patch just adds the infrastructure to allow for the
enforcement of the limits.

injected_file_path_bytes, the configuration option has been changed to
match the name used the API. Configuration backwards compatibility is
maintained using the deprecated options list.

unified limits. Many of the quotas that we previously allowed to be
overridden via the database, will now only be set via Nova
configuration.

overridden via the database, will now only be set via Nova
configuration.

These limits are all about preventing excessive load on the API and
database and have little to do with resource usage. As discussed over
several years at operators meetups, all operators seemed happy to
simplify the system by only setting these limits via configuration.

Local limits include things that just limit items in an API request:
* metadata_items
* injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes

Local limits also include things that are stored in the database:
* key_pairs
* server_groups
* server_group_members

Note that each of the above are counted via a different scope. This new
code ensures that key_pairs are counted per user, server_groups are
counted per project and server_group_members are counted per
server_group.

Note: Previously server_group_member were counted per user inside each
server_group, which has proved very confusing, as adding more users into
a project increases the maximum size of allowed for a server_group.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I0b6f4d29aaee1d71541a95cbecfd0708aac325d2

"}, {'created': '2021-08-29 03:18:18.000000000', 'message': 'Add logic to enforce local api and db limits

Local API and DB limits are limits on resources that are counted either
as an API request parameter (example: server metadata items) or as
records in the database (example: server key pairs).

Future patches will make use of this logic, and actually enforce the
limits. This patch just adds the infrastructure to allow for the
enforcement of the limits.

To stop confusion between injected_file_path_length and
injected_file_path_bytes, the configuration option has been changed to
match the name used the API. Configuration backwards compatibility is
maintained using the deprecated options list.

We are moving all existing quotas to be managed via Keystone's
unified limits.

These local limits are all about preventing excessive load on the API
and database and have little to do with resource usage. These limits
are represented by keystone registered limits only, accordingly.

Local limits include things that just limit items in an API request:
* metadata_items
* injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes

Local limits also include things that are stored in the database:
* key_pairs
* server_groups
* server_group_members

Some resource names have been changed to prepend a prefix of "server_"
in order to disambiguate them from other potential unified limits in
keystone:

* metadata_items => server_metadata_items
* injected_files => server_injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes => server_injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes => server_injected_file_path_bytes
* key_pairs => server_key_pairs

Note that each of the above are counted via a different scope. This new
code ensures that key_pairs are counted per user, server_groups are
counted per project and server_group_members are counted per
server_group.

Note: Previously server_group_member were counted per user inside each
server_group, which has proved very confusing, as adding more users into
a project increases the maximum size of allowed for a server_group.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I0b6f4d29aaee1d71541a95cbecfd0708aac325d2

counted per project and server_group_members are counted per
server_group.

Note: Previously server_group_member were counted per user inside each
server_group, which has proved very confusing, as adding more users into
a project increases the maximum size of allowed for a server_group.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.limit/+/806635

Change-Id: I0b6f4d29aaee1d71541a95cbecfd0708aac325d2
